source.93ac7756: False Positives(Type I Error) occurs when we incorrectly reject a true hypothesis.Lower the value of False Positives, better is the model. This is because, while predicting, if we predict that an employee is not going to leave the job, but later he/she actually leaves the job, then this kind of wrong prediction could further increase Attrition Rate to an alarming range. The False Positives(Type I Error) for all the models can be accessed from the confusion matrix. Gradient Boosting algorithm has the least number of False Positives(Type I Error). Hence, based on the False Positives(Type I Error), Gradient Boosting is the best fit model.

source.b2dfca93: The Receiver Operating Characteristic (ROC) curve is plot which shows the performance of a binary classifier as function of its cut-off threshold. ROC curve is one of the most effective evaluation metrics because it visualizes the accuracy of predictions for a whole range of cutoff values. It essentially shows the true positive rate (TPR) against the false positive rate (FPR) for all possible threshold values. A model is said to be the best model when the ROC is close to the upper left corner. Looking at the ROC curve plot above, the Naive-Bayes, has the curve that is closest to the upper left corner. Hence, based on the ROC plot, Naive-Bayes is the best fit model.

source.2647fe62: Precision - It is the number of True Positive divided by the number of positive results predicted by the classifier. Recall/ Sensitivity - It is the number of True Positives divided by the number of all relevant samples F1 Score - F1 Score is the Harmonic Mean between precision and recall. F1 Score tells how precise the classifier is (how many values it classifies correctly). The greater the F1 Score, the better is the performance of our model. Here, Naive-Bayes has the highest f1_score. Hence, based on the f1_score, Naive-Bayes is the best fit model.
source.fe81e277: The area under the curve (AUC), is an aggregated measure of performance of a binary classifier on all possible threshold values. AUC calculates the area under the ROC curve, and therefore it is between 0 and 1. For any classifier, the higher the AUC of a model the better it is. Here, Gradient Boosting have the highest AUC value. Hence, based on the AUC values, Gradient Boosting is the best fit model.

source.abf318b3: # Step 8: Choosing the Best model There are various ways to evaluate a classification model. Some of them are: 1) Accuracy 2) AUC 3) ROC 4) f1 Score I am evaluating with all these metrics in order to find the best fit model # Confusion Matrix A confusion matrix is an N X N matrix, where N is the number of classes being predicted. Confusion Matrix gives us a matrix as output and describes the complete performance of the model. The correct predictions falls on the diagonal line of the matrix. 4 important terms in Confusion Matrix: True Positives : We predict YES and the actual output is also YES. True Negatives : We predict NO and the actual output is NO. False Positives(Type I Error) : We predict YES but the actual output is NO. False Negatives(Type II error) : We predict NO but the actual output is YES. The Confusion matrix in itself is not a performance measure, but almost all of the performance metrics are based on Confusion Matrix.

source.2c0cb4a1: Here, Gradient Boosting has the highest accuracy rate. But during Data visualization step, we observed that the class distribution is Imbalanced. The dataset has 80% samples of class 0 (the employee is not leaving their job) and 20% samples of class 1(The employee has decided to leave their job). This is the reason why most of the models are getting accuracy above 90% by simply predicting every training sample belonging to class 0. But, when we apply this model to a new test-set, then the test accuracy would drop to less than 60%. In this case, Accuracy metric proves to be a poor indicator of model performance. Therefore, we need to consider other metrics before deciding the best model.
